stem: Click to highlight the findings that require immediate notification of the healthcare provider, indicating a potential complication related to autonomic dysreflexia.
passage: A 45-year-old male client with a T6 spinal cord injury is being assessed. The nurse notes [a severe throbbing headache], [nasal congestion], [a heart rate of 72 bpm], [flushed skin above the level of injury], [pale skin below the level of injury], [diaphoresis above the level of injury], and [the client reports feeling anxious]. The vital signs show [BP 180/110 mmHg]. The client denies any pain.
correctSpans: flushed skin above the level of injury
diaphoresis above the level of injury

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:00 SBAR for Mr. Jones, room 302. Patient reports a sudden, severe headache and feeling 'strange'. Skin above the T6 injury level is flushed and diaphoretic. Noted nasal congestion. Heart rate is 72 bpm, regular. Blood pressure is elevated at 180/110 mmHg. Patient denies pain but reports feeling anxious. Bladder scan ordered stat. Call provider for orders. 
07:15 Foley catheter inserted, draining 500 mL clear yellow urine. Headache persists. BP remains elevated at 178/108 mmHg. Continue to monitor closely.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: No lab results available at this time.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Alert and oriented, anxious. 
HEENT: Severe throbbing headache reported. Nasal congestion present. 
Cardiovascular: Regular heart rate and rhythm. 
Respiratory: Clear and equal breath sounds bilaterally. 
Integumentary: Flushed skin above the level of injury (T6). Pale skin below the level of injury. Diaphoresis noted above the level of injury. 
Neurological: Sensation intact above the level of injury. No motor function below the level of injury.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
Monitor vital signs every 15 minutes. 
Assess for signs and symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia. 
Insert Foley catheter PRN for bladder distention. 
Administer antihypertensive medication PRN per physician order. 
Elevate head of bed to 90 degrees.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: No medications administered at this time.

rationale.correct: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency characterized by a sudden onset of excessively high blood pressure. It is most commonly seen in individuals with spinal cord injuries at or above the T6 level. The body's normal feedback mechanisms to regulate blood pressure are disrupted, leading to an exaggerated response to stimuli below the level of the injury. Immediate notification of the healthcare provider is crucial to prevent severe complications such as stroke, seizure, or even death.
rationale.incorrect: While nasal congestion and anxiety can be associated with autonomic dysreflexia, they are less specific and do not warrant the same level of immediate concern as the other findings. Pale skin below the level of injury and a normal heart rate are not typical signs of autonomic dysreflexia and may indicate other issues.

answerBreakdown.label: a severe throbbing headache
answerBreakdown.content: A severe, throbbing headache is a common symptom of autonomic dysreflexia due to the sudden increase in blood pressure. This requires immediate notification of the healthcare provider.

answerBreakdown.label: nasal congestion
answerBreakdown.content: Nasal congestion can occur in autonomic dysreflexia but is not a primary indicator requiring immediate action. While it should be noted, it doesn't necessitate immediate notification on its own.

answerBreakdown.label: a heart rate of 72 bpm
answerBreakdown.content: A heart rate of 72 bpm is within the normal range and does not indicate autonomic dysreflexia. In fact, bradycardia can sometimes be present.

answerBreakdown.label: flushed skin above the level of injury
answerBreakdown.content: Flushed skin above the level of injury is a classic sign of autonomic dysreflexia due to vasodilation in response to the elevated blood pressure. This requires immediate notification of the healthcare provider.

answerBreakdown.label: pale skin below the level of injury
answerBreakdown.content: Pale skin below the level of injury occurs due to vasoconstriction and is not a sign of autonomic dysreflexia. It may indicate other issues but is not a primary concern in this context.

answerBreakdown.label: diaphoresis above the level of injury
answerBreakdown.content: Diaphoresis (excessive sweating) above the level of injury is another characteristic sign of autonomic dysreflexia. This requires immediate notification of the healthcare provider.

answerBreakdown.label: the client reports feeling anxious
answerBreakdown.content: Anxiety can be a symptom of autonomic dysreflexia, but it is not a primary indicator requiring immediate action. It is important to address the anxiety, but it's secondary to the other critical findings.

answerBreakdown.label: BP 180/110 mmHg
answerBreakdown.content: A blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg is significantly elevated and requires immediate attention in a patient at risk for autonomic dysreflexia. This requires immediate notification of the healthcare provider.

clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention.
Common triggers include bladder distention, bowel impaction, and skin irritation below the level of injury.
Elevating the head of the bed and removing the triggering stimulus are initial steps in management.
Monitor blood pressure frequently and be prepared to administer antihypertensive medications as ordered.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the client's subjective complaints (e.g., anxiety) without considering the objective vital sign changes.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize objective data such as blood pressure and physical assessment findings in conjunction with subjective reports. Remember ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and address the most life-threatening issues first.

mnemonic.title: HEAD
mnemonic.expansion: H-Headache, E-Elevated BP, A-Autonomic signs (flushing, sweating), D-Distention (bladder/bowel). Remember to elevate the head of the bed!
